title: 111_s1819
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Civil Rights Center and Museum Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges the significance of the Greensboro sit-in in 1960, which sparked nonviolent protests against segregation across the United States. Over 70,000 people participated in similar demonstrations by August 1961 in over 60 cities. This led to the establishment of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum, located at the site of the F.W. Woolworth's store where the sit-in movement began, will open on February 1, 2010. It will serve as an archival center and teaching facility exploring the international struggle for civil and human rights, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the movement. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum will officially open on February 1, 2010, marking the 50th anniversary of the sit-in movement at the F.W. Woolworth's store. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue up to 1,000 $1 silver coins commemorating the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted by the Secretary of the Treasury will commemorate the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The design of coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, with inscriptions including the coin's value, the year 2010, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected accordingly. The design of coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may only mint coins during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may only mint coins during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. Sale of coins. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be made at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance. The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for coins minted under this Act before issuance, with sale prices offering a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. Surcharges go to the International Civil Rights Center and Museum for program development. The Comptroller General can audit the Museum's expenditures.
